Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: High-resolution Reconstruction of the South American Monsoon History from Isotopic Proxies and Forward Modeling
Award.AbstractNarration:
The South American summer monsoon (SASM) is of great socio-economic relevance to (sub)tropical South America, delivering water for ecosystem integrity and human activities including agriculture, sanitation, hydropower production and many other socioeconomic purposes. Year-to-year variations in monsoon strength, onset and demise dates have been linked to drought and floods and can cause widespread economic damage. Yet little is known about how the SASM has varied in the past and how it responds to changes in natural (volcanic or solar) and man-made (aerosols and greenhouse gases) perturbations. In this project, a scientist from the State University of New York at Albany and his collaborators will reconstruct the SASM history for the past 1000 years using ice core data from the Quelccaya ice cap in the Peruvian Andes to learn more about the envelope of natural monsoon variability. The Quelccaya site was chosen because almost all snowfall is associated with the SASM (~85%), it contains a long, high-resolution and precisely-dated ice-core record, and has been the focus of long-term on-site climatologic and glaciologic monitoring and calibration programs. Using these on-site data sets, combined with isotope-enabled model simulations for the past millennium, the scientists will develop a so-called forward model that allows reconstructing monsoon variations upstream over the Amazon basin since the year 850 AD.

Given the growing concerns over future changes in monsoon characteristics due to enhanced greenhouse gas concentrations, a better understanding of natural monsoon variability and its sensitivity to external forcing is absolutely essential. The project's progress will be documented on the Quelccaya blog website. The project also includes additional educational aspects such as training of a graduate student and a Postdoctoral Research Associate, and integrating methods and results developed in this project into undergraduate and graduate classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to provide a better understanding of how and why the South American Summer Monsoon (SASM) varied in intensity, both in space and time in the past and to provide methodological advances by which such reconstructions can be achieved. To this end, we developed a model that allows simulating how geochemical signals (hydrogen and oxygen isotopes) in Andean ice cores vary in response to variations in the South American monsoon. Our climate reconstructions for the South American monsoon domain are based primarily on analyses of such stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, deposited during past snowfall events in glacier ice or as a result of rainfall infiltrating in caves and deposited as calcite on stalagmites. Our results demonstrate that the South American monsoon has shown a wide range of variations, including droughts and periods of intense precipitation in the past, in response to solar and volcanic forcing, and as a result of changes in the interhemispheric temperature gradient, leading to shifts in the tropical rainfall belt. These results are relevant as they help improve our understanding of the sensitivity of the monsoon to changes in radiative forcing and they document that the historic range of changes in monsoon intensity and extent is much larger than what is observed in the recent period for which meteorological measurement are available. Such information is critically important as countries in tropical South America strive to adapt to future changes in in climatic extremes, such as droughts or floods.

The project also contributed a great deal to training and outreach. One postdoctoral scientist and one PhD student were funded through this project, which also produced a large amount of research material that is being used on a regular basis in both the undergraduate and graduate classroom. 13 peer-reviewed publications were produced over the 4 years of the project and the PI and collaborators gave over 60 presentations at scientific meetings and at public events, including talks at schools, town halls, teacher’s workshops, business cooperatives and nonprofit groups.
